This is a utility script. If its location is changed, could other scripts depend on it not be able to find it?

> This is a utility script. If its location is changed, could other scripts depend on it not be able to find it?

I have created a soft link like other utility scripts in py3 and kept the main script outside so any other scripts relying on it find it.

@opcoder0 This script was already migrated to Python 3, and was/is running as a Python 3 script in the PTF container. In fact, if my understanding is correct, all PTF scripts on master branch are running in Python 3.

Were there any failures seen because this script was running under Python 2?

> @opcoder0 This script was already migrated to Python 3, and was/is running as a Python 3 script in the PTF container. In fact, if my understanding is correct, all PTF scripts on master branch are running in Python 3.
> 
> Were there any failures seen because this script was running under Python 2?

@saiarcot895 from what I understood most of the files/tests in `ptftests` were indeed already in Python 3. I didn't see any errors/failures. I recently noticed `vnet_vxlan` was still in Python 2 and I moved that (in #12540). I also noticed all of the utilities were moved under `py3` with a symlink pointing back one level up. Hence this PR for sonic.py. The change the tool made was trivial and not really Py3 related. Apart from the files in `ptftests` I believe the other tests in `acstests` and a bunch of others (I have a list) may still be in Python 2. I am in the process of checking those in the coming week.

> hi @byu343 for this one, we need to understand why it take longer to update bgp route, is that a performance issue or not before we decide to change the threshold.

This issue here that needs longer time is only for the case of suppress-fib-pending. It was increase from 1 to 2 by https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/pull/7907/files but seems not enough to ensure always passing the test. The time needed could vary on platforms, depending on factors like CPU speed. We just increase it from 2 to 2.5 to avoid the flakiness of results.

This has broken the following testcases for active-standby dualtor in 202305, 202311 and master -

```
1. qos/test_tunnel_qos_remap.py::test_encap_dscp_rewrite[active-standby]
2. qos/test_tunnel_qos_remap.py::test_bounced_back_traffic_in_expected_queue[active-standby]
3. qos/test_tunnel_qos_remap.py::test_tunnel_decap_dscp_to_queue_mapping
```

```
 @pytest.fixture
 def toggle_all_aa_ports_to_lower_tor(config_active_active_dualtor_active_standby,
 lower_tor_host, upper_tor_host, active_active_ports): # noqa F811
> config_active_active_dualtor_active_standby(lower_tor_host, upper_tor_host, active_active_ports)
E TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```

```
 @pytest.fixture
 def toggle_all_aa_ports_to_rand_selected_tor(config_active_active_dualtor_active_standby,
 rand_selected_dut, rand_unselected_dut, active_active_ports): # noqa F811
> config_active_active_dualtor_active_standby(rand_selected_dut, rand_unselected_dut, active_active_ports)
E TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not callable
```
This is because the check for active-active ports is missing similar to this: https://github.com/sonic-net/sonic-mgmt/blob/master/tests/common/dualtor/dual_tor_utils.py#L1807
